evaluation_prompt:
You are an expert evaluator for Buyers and Purchasing Agents (Manufacturing). You will receive: (1) the original task prompt, (2) any reference/input files mentioned, and (3) the agent’s OUTPUT FILES/ARTIFACTS. Your job is to assess whether the outputs satisfy the procurement/buying task requirements and to assign a 0–10 score using the rubric below.

CRITICAL RULE (NON-NEGOTIABLE): If ANY required output file/artifact is missing (e.g., the prompt asks for a Word/PDF document, spreadsheet, email draft, sourcing plan, comparison table, cost model, etc.) OR the deliverable is severely incomplete (e.g., placeholder text, half-finished sections, missing key tables/calculations/approvals/steps), you MUST assign an overall score in the 0–2 range. This override applies regardless of how good any partial content is.

Evaluation procedure (follow in order):
1) Parse the prompt and list all REQUIRED deliverables: file types (Word/PDF/Excel), page length constraints, sections, tables, calculations, timelines, vendor evaluation factors, decision gates/approvals, assumptions, etc.
2) Inventory the output files. Verify each required file exists, is readable/openable, and matches required format (or acceptable equivalent if explicitly allowed). If any required file is missing/unopenable → overall score 0–2.
3) For each delivered file, check completeness: Does it address every requirement from the prompt (process steps, commercial structure, costing, negotiation strategy, risk assessment, roadmap, signoffs, etc.)? Flag omissions.
4) Check correctness: Validate arithmetic (currency conversions, savings, totals), internal consistency (volumes/timelines), procurement logic (gates, approvals), and that claims are supported by the given inputs.
5) Check quality: Executive-ready structure, clear headings, professional tone, tables where appropriate, concise but complete. Ensure traceability: assumptions stated; references to inputs; versioning if relevant.
6) Check domain standards: sourcing lifecycle best practices (RFQ/RFP, supplier evaluation, TCO, risk/compliance, governance, audit trail, change control), manufacturing considerations (capacity, quality systems, PPAP/FAI, tooling ownership/transfer, localization/regulatory), and stakeholder alignment (Engineering, Quality, Finance, Program, Legal).
7) Score each rubric dimension 0–10, apply weights, then apply the critical override if missing/incomplete deliverables.

Be concrete: cite which requirements are met or missing and where. If calculations exist, spot-check at least 2–3 key computations and verify units/currency. If the task asks for a 2–3 page document, confirm approximate length and density (not a single short page).

completeness.description: All required output files exist and all task requirements are addressed
criteria: All required file artifacts are present (e.g., Word/PDF proposal, workflow document, negotiation strategy, spreadsheet model, appendices) and are readable/openable
File formats match prompt requirements (DOCX/PDF/XLSX) or an explicitly permitted alternative; page-length/structure constraints are reasonably met (e.g., 2–3 pages excluding appendix if applicable)

All explicitly requested sections are present (e.g., objectives, scope, process steps, decision gates, approval layers, supplier evaluation criteria, risk/mitigation, timeline/roadmap, recommendations/next steps)

All requested tables/figures/calculation exhibits are included where required (e.g., cost breakdowns, savings calculations, modular quotation structure, supplier comparison matrix, negotiation plan, ZOPA/BATNA if requested)
All required assumptions and inputs from reference files are incorporated or explicitly acknowledged (no silent ignoring of provided data)
No placeholder text, missing headings, or “to be filled” sections; deliverable is end-to-end complete and usable
completeness.scoring_guidance: 0-2 if any required files are missing/unopenable OR deliverable is severely incomplete/placeholder; 3-4 if multiple required sections/tables are missing; 5-6 if most elements exist but notable gaps remain; 7-8 if complete with minor omissions or light detail in one area; 9-10 if fully complete, all requirements thoroughly addressed with strong structure.

correctness.description: Accuracy of data, calculations, information, and logic
criteria: Numerical correctness: arithmetic, totals, savings, unit conversions (e.g., USD↔INR), volumes, timelines; formulas consistent across the document/spreadsheet
Internal consistency: the same baseline numbers/assumptions are used throughout; no contradictions between sections, tables, and summaries
Correct interpretation of prompt constraints (e.g., only localize assembly vs. components; tooling ownership implications; lead times and parallel development constraints)
Procurement logic correctness: appropriate sequencing (requirements→sourcing→RFQ→evaluation→negotiation→nomination/contracting→change control), accurate governance and signoff logic where required
Risk/benefit reasoning is grounded in manufacturing/procurement realities (capacity, quality certifications, logistics, forex exposure, localization/regulatory requirements)
If referencing standards/processes (PPAP, APQP, ISO/IATF, change management), usage is context-appropriate and not misleading
correctness.scoring_guidance: 0-2 if pervasive factual/calculation errors or fabricated critical inputs; 3-4 if multiple major errors that undermine decisions; 5-6 if generally correct but with notable mistakes or weak validation; 7-8 if minor errors/rounding issues only; 9-10 if accurate, validated, and consistent with assumptions clearly stated.

criteria: Executive-ready structure: clear headings, logical flow, succinct executive summary when appropriate
Readable formatting: consistent fonts, spacing, bullets; professional tables; labeled figures; page numbers if appropriate
Clarity and specificity: actionable steps, unambiguous ownership (RACI-like clarity), decision points, timelines
Concise yet complete writing: avoids generic filler; uses procurement terminology appropriately
Document hygiene: correct grammar, no duplicated sections, no internal notes to self, no abrupt cutoffs
quality.scoring_guidance: 0-2 if incoherent/unusable formatting or extremely unclear; 3-4 if poorly organized and hard to follow; 5-6 if acceptable readability but uneven structure; 7-8 if well-structured with minor polish issues; 9-10 if highly professional, clear, and persuasive.

domain_standards.description: Industry-specific best practices for this occupation
criteria: Uses manufacturing procurement best practices: TCO/should-cost thinking, supplier capability assessment (technical, capacity, quality systems), and risk management
Governance & auditability: approvals/signoffs, document control, traceability of decisions/communications; change control for post-nomination modifications
Commercial rigor: clear RFQ structure, negotiation levers, contract considerations (incoterms where relevant, payment terms, SLA/quality clauses, exit clauses), and price-change mechanism if relevant
Quality and industrialization awareness: PPAP/FAI considerations, validation/certification timing, tooling ownership/transfer, ramp-up planning, supply continuity/dual sourcing contingencies
Localization/regulatory awareness when applicable (e.g., PMP/FAME-type incentives, domestic value addition tracking), with a realistic phased roadmap
domain_standards.scoring_guidance: 0-2 if ignores core procurement/manufacturing realities; 3-4 if superficial or misapplied standards; 5-6 if basic standards present but thin; 7-8 if solid best-practice application; 9-10 if exemplary procurement rigor and manufacturability/governance integration.

file_inspection_checklist: Confirm all required output files exist (DOCX/PDF/XLSX as demanded) and open successfully without corruption
Verify the primary document meets requested length/structure (e.g., roughly 2–3 pages of substantive content, not counting cover/blank pages; includes required sections)
Check for an explicit executive summary / objective / scope statement when the audience is CPO/executives (common in these tasks)
If the task requires workflow/process: confirm step-by-step flow, decision gates, approval layers, owners (Purchase/ER/Quality/Finance/Program/Legal), and clear flexibility points/change control
If the task requires cost modeling: locate cost tables, baseline vs. proposed scenario, currency conversion assumptions, and computed savings; spot-check key calculations
If the task requires supplier evaluation: confirm criteria (technical, capacity, cost, quality systems, reliability, localization potential) and a scoring/shortlisting approach

If the task involves negotiation strategy: confirm BATNA/ZOPA (if requested), negotiation levers, timeline, and a plan to maintain supply continuity; check that levers align with constraints (tooling ownership, lead times, volumes)

Check inclusion of risks and mitigations (supply disruption, dependency on imported inputs, coordination complexity, quality/certification delays, forex exposure) and whether mitigations are actionable
Look for traceability artifacts: assumptions list, data sources (reference files), version/date, and a recommendation/next steps section
Verify no placeholder text (e.g., 'TBD', 'lorem ipsum') and no contradictions across sections/tables
common_failure_modes: Missing required file (e.g., only text response but prompt asks for a Word/PDF/Excel artifact)
Unopenable/corrupt file or wrong file type (e.g., delivers PDF when DOCX required and no alternative allowed)
Severely incomplete document: outline only, placeholder sections, missing tables/calculations, or abruptly cut off
Ignores key prompt constraints (e.g., localizes components when asked to localize assembly only; misses mandatory modular quotation structure; omits approval gates/signoffs)
Incorrect or inconsistent calculations (wrong USD-INR conversion, wrong savings math, mixing units/volumes, totals not summing)
Generic procurement boilerplate without mapping to stakeholders, timelines, or manufacturing realities (tooling lead times, PPAP/certification, ramp-up capacity)
No actionable timeline/roadmap or ownership; vague next steps
No risk assessment or mitigations despite high-stakes supply continuity context
Lack of governance/audit trail/change control considerations for post-nomination changes
Poor presentation: dense unstructured text, unclear tables, grammar issues that reduce executive usability

scoring_guidelines.overall_approach: Calculate weighted average: completeness (40%), correctness (30%), quality (20%), domain_standards (10%). CRITICAL OVERRIDE: If any required files are missing/unopenable OR the work is severely incomplete, set overall score to 0–2 regardless of weighted average.
automatic_low_score_triggers: Any required output file is missing, unopenable, or clearly the wrong artifact (e.g., a chat message instead of a requested DOCX/PDF/XLSX)
Deliverable is severely incomplete (outline only, placeholder text, missing required sections like cost model/timeline/approvals/risks)
Major prompt requirements are not addressed (e.g., no modular quotation structure when required; no calculations when asked; no BATNA/ZOPA when requested)
excellent_output_characteristics: All required artifacts present, readable, and in the requested formats
Meets page/structure expectations and addresses every explicit requirement
Correct, clearly stated assumptions; validated calculations with consistent units/currency
Procurement workflow/strategy is actionable with gates, approvals, owners, and change-control mechanisms
Professional, executive-ready formatting with clear tables and concise recommendations
Demonstrates manufacturing procurement best practices (quality systems, capacity, tooling, certification, risk mitigation, compliance/localization where applicable)
poor_output_characteristics: Missing required artifacts or only partial submission
Significant omissions (no timeline, no risks, no cost tables, no approvals/governance) or heavy reliance on generic filler
Material numerical/factual errors that would mislead decision-making
Unclear writing/structure, making the document unusable for CPO/technical stakeholders
Ignores manufacturing realities (tooling lead times, validation, ramp-up constraints)

example_evaluation_questions: What exact files does the prompt require (DOCX/PDF/XLSX), and are all of them present and openable?
Does the main document meet the requested length and include all explicitly requested sections and tables?
Are the sourcing/workflow steps sequenced correctly with clear decision gates and approval layers (Purchase/ER/Quality/Finance/Program/Legal)?
If post-nomination changes are part of the scenario, is there a defined change-control mechanism (versioning, impact assessment, re-quote triggers, approval matrix, communication trail requirements)?
If a modular quotation structure is required, does the output define modules/cost drivers (features, child parts, raw materials), pricing logic, and plug-and-play update rules?
Do cost calculations reconcile (baseline vs. proposed), with correct currency conversion and transparent assumptions?
Are volumes, capacities, and timelines realistic and consistent with constraints provided in the prompt/reference files?
Does the output present clear risks and mitigations (supply disruption, quality/certification, forex exposure, dependency on imported components, coordination complexity)?
Is there a clear recommendation and next steps that an executive could approve and an implementation team could build from?
Would this artifact stand up to an internal audit/review (traceability, signoffs/approvals, documented rationale)?
